ai.summary: The Goathland to Grosmont Rail Trail is a 20.4 km hike along the historic North Yorkshire Moors Railway bed between Goathland and Grosmont in the UK. Labeled as hard, the route combines long distance with varied terrain and potential exposed moorland sections, demanding good fitness and careful footing.
ai.terrain_summary: Primarily follows a former railway bed with surfaces of compacted gravel and occasional ballast patches. The trail is mostly flat to gently undulating, interspersed with short climbs. Expect uneven, muddy spots after rain and exposed winds on moorland sections. Gates, stiles, and farm tracks may appear; weather can change quickly, so be prepared for a range of conditions.
ai.safety_notes: - Distance is roughly 20 km; ensure you are fit for a long, continuous hike. - UK weather can be variable; carry waterproofs and extra layers. - Bring a map or GPS, a fully charged phone, and tell someone your plans. - Wear sturdy footwear with good grip; watch for mud and loose gravel. - Be aware of railway signage and stay clear of any active lines; follow posted notices. - Stay hydrated and carry snacks; include a small first aid kit. - If hiking solo, consider the increased risk and plan a safe return.
recommended_gear: Sturdy hiking boots with good ankle support
Waterproof jacket and extra insulating layers
Hat and gloves for wind and cold
Hydration system or several liters of water plus snacks
Map and compass or GPS device
Fully charged mobile phone with offline maps
ai.best_seasons: Late spring to early autumn (roughly April–October) is ideal due to longer daylight and more stable conditions. The hike is achievable year-round, but winter carries more mud, wind, and shorter daylight; plan accordingly.
